comment.body: Maybe like Firefox OS and CyanogenMod have transformed into a community project (B2g OS, lineage OS), Ubuntu mobile will be the same.

@ulrichard: I don't use CyanogenMod too. Before I used a Blackberry Q10 (and you should know that Blackberry has officially discarded their own OS), I switched to Yotaphone 2 about half a year ago and I enjoy the eink screen very much. Back to the topic, I believe Ubuntu mobile developers and contributors won't give up their lovely kid. And I remember that Debian Community is [developping universal mobile system](https://wiki.debian.org/Mobile), this is very promising. And [this](https://wiki.debian.org/Mobile/Ubuntu) ;)
Don't know how to convert a whole nodejs app, but once I used [Webpack](https://webpack.github.io/) to convert npm lib, hope it helpful

@Nofish: Idea: Using hub as language filter.
Therefore at the beginning users are suggested to choose a hub by language (and interests, if some people like to create a specific group, like EN-anarchy, MULTI-multiculturism). Also users are able to view content from a specific hub (or local hub timeline). And it will be nice if users are easy to migrate to other hubs as s/he likes, and/or users can log in different hub using different ID.

The flagship is mastodon.social, maintained by main dev https://mastodon.social/@Gargron. The most active one I guess is mstdn.jp, so most japanese.
I guess there is no compeitition there, you can follow other people from any instances. Actually many devs dislike an instance with too many users, because it's not a good thing for decentralization.
Also I have a personal Gnusocial instance and I use it a lot. You can follow [me](https://social.binchan.xyz/chbinnc) if you join one :3

@Kaffie: They use the same protocol "OStatus", so it can be said that they are connected. Mastodon is developed by Ruby on Rails. Gnusocial is mainly developed by PHP and Javascript, and has been existing for a long time before Mastodon came out.

Added :) New version is available in [my blog](/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:3), [my gallery](/1ADGCZCvC6wCf5GwCY23H9uwKyRiixoLt6/dark/theme/2017/06/22/zeronet-dark-theme.html) and [git.gnu.io](https://git.gnu.io/chbinnc/Userscripts/raw/master/Userstyles/zeronet-dark-theme.userstyle.css)

Just tested it with my ZeroMessage widget, works very well! Before I searched a workaround online, and it scared me that all the solutions I saw needed jquery library. Finally I found [a bloated solution](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38738442/is-there-a-way-to-make-a-textbox-auto-expand-without-jquery) compare to yours. Thx.

Read the news from another source, just experimental now, but really fascinating. Also remind me of this one: [the U.S. Federal Communications Commission has, for the first time, given a company permission to build a next-generation satellite Internet service that promises to be both ultra-fast and affordable.](http://internethalloffame.org/blog/2017/07/28/one-step-closer-internet-everyone)

Jetzt gibt es [Hub timeline](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/1503050901). Ich versuche Language Filter zu implementieren. Aber ich kann nicht sagen, wann es fertig sein wird.

@Krixano: @Nofish: Me too. My ZeroNet sometimes hangs up (can't open any site) and if I pause some ZeroMe hub updates, everything works again (some just took forever to update and finally failed, check files didn't work). Sometimes I just wait for several minutes until the ZeroMe hubs fail to update their files.

> The device will run the company's PureOS platform, a derivative of Debian GNU/Linux, but it will also be able to run most‚Äã‚Äã GNU+Linux‚Äã‚Äã distributions. And since Purism wants to give you as much control over the device as possible, it will release the device's source code, so you can edit it whenever you want.

Merger site feature like Git Center so user can fully control his own content but still you and later other moderators can moderate the content by configuring ZeroMedium itself.

@Krixano: My suggestion: don't assume too much, or simply ignore them and focus on what you want to focus, or respectfully ask her/him directly (or by a middle man) for explanation and for what s/he is thinking. Using snide comment to reply snide comment won't take any effect imho :)

@Krixano: I see. Just my opinion (maybe I still don't get the situation very well): there are all kinds of people there, and maybe have very different mindset. Like, some people don't ask others questions for answer, or respond to others for discussion, one may construct his words unconsciously or deliberately and just to see/analyze how the replier reacts. Being angry and raising attention are ok, better than silence in quite many situations, still you may like to think of some other strategies and at least avoid yourself from getting disturbed and also keep the environment/atmosphere enjoyable for others.
@Krixano: Thanks for sharing your opinion first, for me it's ok. Btw, your deleted post will display as orphan post on Sakana, and I can still see my comments.

@ulrichard: Any preferred [Hugo theme](https://themes.gohugo.io/)? I can take a try.
Taking a look at your clearnet site, similar theme I can find are [[mainroad]](https://themes.gohugo.io/mainroad/) (GPLv2), [[Hugo-Octopress ]](https://themes.gohugo.io/hugo-octopress/) (MIT).
Manually adding mobile support shouldn't be a hard job for me.
[[ZeroMail]](/mail.zeronetwork.bit/?to=binchan2)

@ulrichard: with hugo-universal-theme, I can make it work with `hugo server -w` (so it should work on Apache) and on ZeroNet (including contact form, at least it shows up correctly, haven't tested the function yet).

With `hugo server -w`, everything is fine, zero external dependencies (checked by uMatrix).

On ZeroNet, compare to Apache, different `config.toml`, `partials/head.html`, `partials/scripts.html` files are needed (small changes). There are external css sources from `fonts.gstatic.com`... Easy to clean.
Home picture wall doesn't work, so need further investigation.

There are probably some other things needed to test. If you feel ok, I can move on and solve the issues above.

Btw, never see anyone (trying to) do paid work publicly in this way XD
--- ---
Explanation: external sources can all be downloaded locally, some elements don't show up correctly mainly because of path problem, clearnet site begins wIth example.com/, but ZeroNet begins with localhost:43110/site_auth_address/. Most templates are mobile friendly... and for ZeroNet we just need to add viewport to content.json. So your demands are not hard to solve, except that it's a bit time consuming.
„Åë„Å£„Åì„ÇìÔºÅX3

@ulrichard: I prefer to set the price beginning with 0, which means I accept any amount of payment. You can decide how much you would like to pay according to how many things I have done, or ask one of your webdev friends for help and evaluation.

Reasons:
* I'm just an amateur webdev and later you may still need a profesional dev for making a more professional web.
* I'm not learning webdev for making money, I'm doing it for participating in global collaboration, and some more general purpose.
* Even though paid work means responsibility/duty, I will do it for fun :D

Model:
* I will put this job in high priority and keep my work in a good shape: a patch to your repository, reproducabie (like using script to automatically download third-party resources to local), concise/detailed explanation, easy to use.
* For the requests in your list and issues I've found, I will try to finish them in one week. Deadline is two weeks. If longer, this job will probably become a burden to me. Then I will clean up the things I've done and submit the patch to your repository.
* Part of the job is probably beyond my ability, like testing for some platform (Edge, Safari) (I can test IE by VM, but I may prefer not to touch some issues from them...).
* You can decide whether to accept my patch or not, request further improvement for free (even two weeks later) (It's my work, so I will feel happy if it can get better), in contrast I may give up the job in the middle, and reject some feature request.

Is this good enough/acceptable for you? Any suggestions are welcome.

Btw, using ZeroMe for such thing is quite an innovation! XD

@ulrichard: Thanks! For your demands in the list and the issues I found, I think it's not necessary to make smaller pull requests, I will try to keep my commits step by step so you can easily track every part. First let me take a good sleep :)

@ulrichard: So.. I finished my work. Sorry for being immature that I didn't realize that contact form needs extra implementation. So it still can't fit your demand. I have some ideas about implementing it but I'm not confident if I can finish it right now. And you don't need to pay me before you really use my work.

> I know userstyles work for clearnet sites. 

@Kaffie: Nice to hear it, before I tried github dark and it didn't work, At that time Stylus was still in beta. I just checked it and the beta label was removed! Hope it will get better and support ZN (probably iframe as you mentioned) soon.

Looks like original file upload won't work when it's larger than ~10 MB, because in `./data/users/content.json` of official ZeroMe hub there is `"max_size_optional": 10000000`, and interestingly optional file doesn't have type limit placeholder `files_allowed_optinal`, so gif, mp4, mp3, zip.. are allowed?
